The art hidden beneath Parliament House The public art collection in Parliament House isn't so public, with thousands of pieces hidden from view in a subterranean storage room.
PT3M21S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings The Parliament House art collection nobody gets to see Shakespeare exhibition at Parliament House showcases top visual artists Craig Kelly loves art. The Liberal MP – a former small businessman and first grade rugby union player – visits galleries whenever he travels. Last year he requested a personal tour of the Parliament House art collection.
People can call me a philistine, that's fine. In this job you need a thick hide   
But one painting hanging on the walls of Parliament House has made him as fiery as Rothko's Orange, Red, Yellow .
The Witches by Wendy Sharpe on display at Parliament House in Canberra. Photo: Andrew Meares 
On the first floor of the building, not far from the House of Representatives chamber, an exhibit titled The Art of Shakespeare is on display. It's a showcase of 14 works inspired by the Bard's plays – including The Witches , an eye-catching piece by Wendy Sharpe.
Advertisement A painting based on Shakespeare's famous tale of ambition and betrayal seems a perfect fit for a building that has had five prime ministers over the past five years.
But Kelly says the prominent female buttocks featured in the work are inappropriate, even if the exhibit comes with a "partial nudity" warning. 
The artwork on display inside Parliament House. Photo: Andrew Meares 
"Appalling" is how he labels the work – and much of the contemporary art on display in Parliament House.
"Obviously everyone has different tastes but I would say a naked backside is a bit far – the average punter on the street would question this," he said.
"People can call me a philistine, that's fine. In this job you need a thick hide."
Liberal MP Craig Kelly. Photo: Andrew Meares 
(The insult of philistine featured heavily in the 2008 debate over artist Bill Henson's photographs featuring naked teenagers.)
Sharpe, a winner of the prestigious Archibald and Sulman prizes, has described the work as "lurid".
"That's the word; these witches don't pale into the distance, they're really out there, screaming and you can't avoid them – incredibly powerful and not shrinking violets," she said last month.
Art collection manager, Justine van Mourik with some of the hundreds of pieces of artwork stored beneath Parliament House. Photo: Rohan Thomson 
Kelly says Parliament should feature more works depicting important scenes from Australian history – and fewer abstract and edgy contemporary works.
"They have some marvellous historical pieces that people would love to see but they are hidden and locked away," he says.
"There's a lot of people that come to visit Parliament just for the artwork. It's a tourist attraction in itself. I personally would like to see more historical artwork."
Detail from The Witches by Wendy Sharpe. Photo: Andrew Meares 
Of the Parliament's 6000-strong collection, about 2000 works are in storage at any given time. The rest hang on the walls of Parliament, Admiralty House, Government House or are on loan to other galleries.
Kelly uploaded a photo of the painting on his Facebook page this week, posing the question: "Do you think this painting is suitable for Parliament House?"
So far, the respondents are firmly on his side.
"Horrid", "not art, that's crap", "grotesque", "bloody awful" are some of the responses.
One Facebook user could even detect the sinister influence of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, the art lover who famously owns two Henson photographs.
"This is what happens when the progressives take control," the commenter wrote. "Standards slip."
